item.title: My Hero Academia's Next Game Already Looks Like A Big Leap Forward From One's Justice
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Following rumors that a new My Hero Academia fighting game was in the works, Bandai Namco confirmed the news by announcing My Hero Academia: All's Justice during its summer showcase. The 3D fighting game is being developed alongside the anime series' final season, and as such, will feature the series' final fights, allowing players to experience the conclusion of the popular manga firsthand.

After showing off the game's next-level visuals in a short trailer, Bandai Namco offered a first look at combat and a brief overview of its mechanics. According the game's director, Aoba Miyazaki, one of the highlights of My Hero Academia: All's Justice is a "huge roster" that, for the first time ever, includes all students from class 1-A. From this roster, players will assemble a team of three characters who can be switched out seamlessly during fights, allowing them to chain together attacks and quirk abilities. A new Rising system will also players to "significantly boost" the power of their characters by unleashing "their full potential," though the studio did not specify exactly what that might entail.

However, Bandai Namco did confirm it will be sharing more about My Hero Academia: All's Justice in the near future. For the time being, players can wishlist the upcoming title on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X.

The announcement of My Hero Academia: All's Justice comes more than five years after the last My Hero Fighting Game, One's Justice 2, was released back in March 2020. One's Justice 2 was considered a significant step up from its predecessor, One's Justice, but failed to garner the sort of praise reserved for Bandai Namco's Naruto fighting game, Ultimate Ninja Storm, or its Dragon Ball fighting game, FighterZ.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: All Games Shown At The Xbox Showcase In June Are "Safe" - Report
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Microsoft laid off numerous Xbox developers, canceled games, and closed at least one studio this week as part of the company's latest round of significant cuts. The company still has 40+ projects that remain in the works, and it's now been reported that everything shown during the Xbox Games Showcase in June remains in development.

Windows Central reported that "everything" in that showcase is "safe." Some of the games on display in the showcase included Call of Duty: Black Ops 7, The Outer Worlds 2, Grounded 2, Keeper, Gears of War: Reloaded, and Clockwork Revolution. Some games not shown at the event, like State of Decay 3, are going forward as well, the report said. Separately, a source told Variety that "every game" on display at the event in June is "continuing on."

In terms of games that are not going forward, Rare's Everwild and the new Perfect Dark have been canceled--neither appeared at the Showcase, fueling theories about what that could mean. Microsoft's Matt Booty said in a memo to staff that "several unannounced projects" have been canceled as well, and one of them could be the reported MMO Blackbird from ZeniMax Online Studios.

Booty said the game cancellations, layoffs, and closure of Perfect Dark studio The Initiative "reflect a broader effort to adjust priorities and focus resources to set up our teams for greater success within a changing industry landscape. We did not make these choices lightly, as each project and team represent years of effort, imagination, and commitment."

Going forward, Booty claimed Xbox's portfolio strategy is "unchanged," and that is to make great games filled with "new stories, worlds, and characters." He specified that Microsoft has 40+ games in "active development" and teased a "strong slate" for 2026 that will include the new Fable, Gears of War: E-Day, the next Forza game, and a possible Halo release.

Microsoft's cuts to Xbox came as part of a wider cost-cutting program that saw the technology giant lay off about 4% of its global workforce, amounting to around 9,000 people.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Prime Day Echo Dot Deal Makes Spider-Man Your Friendly Virtual Assistant
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

While Prime Day 2025 doesn’t officially begin until July 8, there are already some great early deals on Amazon devices. The fifth generation Echo Dot, for example, is just $32--the lowest price we’ve seen this year. And if you’re a Marvel fan, consider pairing it with the Limited Edition Echo Dot Spider-Man Stand. Modeled after Spider-Man’s iconic mask, it’s a fun choice for a kid’s room or game room. The stand is seeing its first-ever discount ahead of Prime Day, dropping the price to $30 (was $40).

Limited Edition Echo Dot Spider-Man Stand

$30 (was $40) / Bundle it with a new Echo Dot for $32 (was $50)

This fun little Echo Dot Stand is compatible with the 4th and 5th generation Echo Dot. It’s designed so you can easily slot the smart speaker into the top of the mask, with a small cutout on the back for the power cable. The coolest part of the stand? Spidey’s eyes will glow, as the light ring on your Echo can shine through its translucent cover. The light adjusts automatically--so the darker the room, the brighter his eyes.

The stand doesn’t bring any additional functionality to your Echo, but it’s a fun way to display it in your home. It also won’t hinder your ability to operate the smart speaker, as all its buttons and ports are still easily accessible. As mentioned, this is the first discount we’ve seen for the stand, and it's prominently featured on Amazon's home page, so we wouldn't be surprised if it sells out.

Amazon Prime Day Smart Speaker & Display Deals

Unless otherwise stated, all of the deals below are for the newest editions of Amazon's various Echo smart home devices.

  • Spider-Man Echo Dot Stand -- $30 ($40)
  • Echo Dot Smart Speaker -- $32 ($50)
  • Echo Dot + Iron Man Stand -- $62 ($90)
  • Baby Yoda Echo Dot Stand -- $15 ($28)
  • Echo Dot Kids Smart Speaker -- $32 ($60)
  • Echo Dot Battery Base -- $33 ($40)
  • Echo Pop Smart Speaker -- $22 ($40)
  • Echo Pop Kids Smart Speaker -- $22 ($50)
  • Echo Spot Smart Alarm Clock -- $45 ($80)
  • Echo Show 5 Smart Display -- $60 ($90)
  • Echo Show 5 Kids Smart Display -- $60 ($100)
    Echo Show 8 Smart Display -- $110 ($150)
  • Echo Show 8 Battery Base -- $35 ($50)
  • Echo Buds Wireless Earbuds with ANC -- $45 ($140)
  • Echo Frames Smart Glasses -- $130 ($300)

Amazon previously released an Iron Man Echo Dot Stand last holiday. Iron Man fans can still grab that model today, but it's selling for its full $40 MSRP. The bundles are discounted, however, allowing you to pick up an Echo Dot (5th Gen) and Iron Man Stand for $62 (was $90). That’s the same price you’d pay if you picked up the discounted Spider-Man Stand and an Echo Dot (5th Gen), making it a good choice if you don’t yet have the smart speaker.

Speaking of the Echo Dot, the standalone speaker is available for $32 (was $50), though you can also find it bundled with an Amazon Basics Smart Color Bulb for $37 (was $63). Consider spending the extra few bucks on this option, as you’ll be able to control the bulb via voice commands with your new smart speaker. The bulb typically costs $13, so you’re saving a nice chunk of change for Prime Day. If you’re not sold on the Echo Dot, the bulb can be bundled with several other products.

A bunch of Amazon devices are discounted for Prime Day, including the affordable Echo Pop. This smart speaker is now just $22 (was $40), and while it doesn't sound quite as robust as the Echo Dot, it's a good choice for small spaces that don't need the 360-degree soundscape provided by the Dot. This is the best price we've seen in 2025, and it's not likely to stick around past Prime Day. The Echo Spot, meanwhile, is an excellent bedside companion, as its small display makes it a good alternative to a traditional alarm clock. Its current price of $45 (was $80) matches its lowest price ever.

While these and other Echo devices are great gadgets, keep in mind they're not compatible with the Spider-Man Stand.

For private listening with built-in Alexa support, check out the Amazon Echo Buds with active noise cancellation for only $45 (was $140).

item.title: Sony's New 4K Blu-Ray Player Gets Huge Early Prime Day Discount Weeks After Its Launch
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Ahead of Prime Day 2025, Amazon is offering a stellar deal on the new 2025 edition of Sony's popular UBP-X700U 4K Blu-ray Player. The UBP-X700U launched a few weeks ago--Amazon started selling it on June 9--but you can already save more than $80 on Sony's newest mid-range media player. Physical media enthusiasts can snag this $300 4K Blu-ray player for only $218 for a limited time at Amazon or Best Buy. You could use some of the money you're saving on Criterion Collection Blu-rays while they are on sale for 50% off.

Alternatively, you can get the more budget-friendly Sony BDP-S1700U 1080p Blu-ray Player for $85 (was $95). This is also a brand-new release from Sony and is currently the best-selling new media player on Amazon.

Sony UBP-X700U 4K Blu-ray Player (2025 model)

$218 (was $300)

Sony Blu-ray players have a solid reputation, and the X700U model on sale offers a number of features found in some of Sony's high-end line of Blu-ray players. It plays 4K Blu-rays in native 4K UHD (2160p) resolution and supports HDR10, which improves picture brightness.

It comes with an HDMI cable, but we'd recommend grabbing a second 4K cable if you don't have a spare. That's because the player has two HDMI out ports. The main one is for video and audio, and is the only one you must use, but the second output is dedicated to audio. Separating audio from video output produces a richer, clearer sound, so dual ports are common on dedicated 4K Blu-ray players. It's one of the benefits of using a media player for Blu-rays instead of a game console like the PS5 or Xbox Series X. You can grab an Amazon Basics 4K HDMI cable for $6 right now.

The UBP-X700U also has a Coaxial SPDIF, which can be connected to speakers, soundbars, and TVs. In- terms of audio support, the UBP-X700U is equipped with high-end audio enhancements, including Dolby Atmos and DTS:X.

One of the coolest features of dedicated Blu-ray players like the X700U is picture upscaling. The X700U can read 4K Blu-ray, standard Blu-ray, and DVDs. When enabled, the built-in tech will enhance the resolution of standard Blu-rays and DVDs.

While we haven't tested the 2025 edition of the X700U, the upscaling feature on previous iterations was quite impressive. Standard 1080p Blu-rays can look pretty darn close to 4K resolution, and 480p resolution DVDs are substantially better. Honestly, without upscaling tech, DVDs generally look terrible on modern 4K and HD panels. That said, upscaled output varies, and sometimes there are jagged edges or noticeable oddities that won't be appealing to viewers looking for an authentic experience.

For a higher-end 4K player with built-in streaming and voice assistant capabilities, check out the Panasonic DP-UB820-K. This is one of the most popular premium models on the market today. Normally $500, you can get it for $404 ahead of Prime Day.

If you take advantage of one of these media player deals and want to pair it with some new movies, check out our roundup of the best Criterion Collection deals available now. A staggeringly impressive list of Criterion releases are 50% off at Amazon. Along with the giant list in our roundup, we built this custom Amazon hub filled with Criterion Collection deals to make it easy to find the best offers.

item.title: Leaked Call Of Duty Collab With American Dad Reveals Skins For Stan And Roger
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Season 4 Reloaded is now live in Call of Duty: Black Ops 6 and Warzone, and the update is themed around cartoon content and a Beavis and Butt-Head collaboration. Data miners have now discovered a potential American Dad crossover in the new game files, meaning more cartoon skins could be on the way.

Data miners have leaked Call of Duty bundles for both Stan and Roger from Seth MacFarlane's American Dad animated sitcom. These leaks also suggest a price of 2,800 CoD Points ($25) for each bundle, which is typical for the pricing on most bundles for Call of Duty's big IP crossovers.

It's uncertain when this American Dad collaboration might arrive. If this content is indeed still planned for Call of Duty, it's possible it might arrive with Season 4 Reloaded to continue the cartoon theme, or this could be planned for a later crossover event in Season 5.

The Beavis and Butt-Head event is live from now until July 30, and there are free and premium rewards available to unlock. This includes two free DLC weapons, free skins for Todd and Coach Buzzcut, and paid skins for both Beavis and Butt-Head.

In addition to Beavis and Butt-Head, Season 4 Reloaded adds cel-shaded maps, new game modes, and more. Check out the gallery below to see everything new in Season 4 Reloaded. The Season 4 Reloaded patch notes detail major weapon attachment changes, updates to Zombies Grief mode, and a wacky new Warzone mode.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/leaked-call-of-duty-collab-with-american-dad-reveals-skins-for-stan-and-roger/1100-6532922/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f
